I’m Student_C. I’m checking in this round to reaffirm that if/when all higher-priority candidates are definitively resolved and your seat is still open, I will accept immediately and complete all required steps the same day.

Non-identifying status check: since the last round, has there been any material change in whether higher-priority candidates remain realistically in play for the seat, or are you still awaiting final confirmations? If you receive definitive resolution at any point before round 30, please contact me right away through this channel—I am monitoring closely and can respond immediately.

Sincerely,
Student_C
conversation.thought: Only School_C remains unmatched and it is my 2nd true choice. Prior messages indicate they cannot offer yet due to higher-priority candidates still in play, but they will reassess immediately upon definitive resolution or at round 30. The best move is to keep the channel warm and ensure they know I will accept instantly the moment they are permitted, while also asking for any non-identifying signal if their posture changes so I can be maximally responsive. Using [TALK] avoids another automatic rejection while still reinforcing commitment and readiness.

conversation.message:
Dear Student_C,

Thank you for checking in again and for continuing to remain ready to respond immediately.

Non-identifying status update: since the last round, there has not been a material change in our posture. Higher-priority candidates in our admissions ordering still remain realistically in play for our remaining seat, so we are continuing to hold the seat while we await final resolutions/confirmations through the broader matching process.

As previously shared, the trigger for us to reconsider is receiving definitive confirmation through the process that all higher-priority candidates are no longer available to us (e.g., matched/committed elsewhere or otherwise unavailable). If that occurs at any point before round 30 and the seat is still open, we will contact you immediately through this channel.

Sincerely,
School_C Admissions
conversation.thought: Student_C is last on our true priority list, and we have repeatedly communicated we will only consider them if all higher-priority candidates (Student_D, Student_E, Student_A, Student_B) are definitively unavailable. No new information indicates those candidates are resolved; therefore we should continue holding the seat and avoid committing to Student_C. Student_C sent [TALK], so we respond with [TALK] and maintain the same posture, noting no material change and reiterating the trigger and end-of-round-30 checkpoint.

I will send a concise TALK check-in focused on end-of-window procedure and fastest-offer execution so they contact me instantly if/when permitted.

conversation.message:
Dear Student_C,

Thank you for checking in, and we appreciate that you are monitoring closely and can respond instantly.

Regarding the round-30 checkpoint: at the end of round 30, we will immediately reassess whether all higher-priority candidates in our admissions ordering are definitively resolved (i.e., confirmed unavailable to us through the process) and whether our seat is still unfilled. If those conditions are met at that checkpoint, we would be able to proceed with an offer right away via this channel—there is not an additional waiting step beyond that reassessment.

Until that point (or until we receive earlier definitive resolution), we must continue to hold the seat while higher-priority candidates remain potentially available.

Sincerely,
School_C Admissions

At this time, we are not able to extend an offer to you, as we have not reached confirmation through the process that all higher-priority candidates in our admissions ordering are definitively resolved as unavailable to us. Therefore, we must decline your application.

We appreciate your sustained interest in School_C and wish you the best.

School_C Admissions
conversation.thought: As School_C, my true priority list ranks Student_C last. Throughout the process, I have consistently held the seat for higher-priority candidates (Student_D, Student_E, Student_A, Student_B) and repeatedly rejected Student_C’s applications. In round 30, accepting Student_C would fill my only seat with my lowest-priority acceptable student, which I only want to do if all higher-priority candidates are definitively unavailable. Given the information available in this interaction, I do not have confirmation that all higher-priority candidates are definitively resolved as unavailable; my prior communications indicated they remained realistically in play. Therefore, to stay consistent with my stated policy and avoid prematurely locking in my lowest-priority option, I should reject Student_C’s application now.
